Your intentions were good. Nevertheless, what you did was totally miss the boat on atheist and nontheist philosophies. It really indicates that you haven't taken the time to really understand us. At its basic level, theists and nontheists differ fundamentally on the issue of faith. A theist values faith over truth. Belief in things not seen and the mystery of god are paradigms valued in theism. A nontheist (including atheists) value reason, logic, and the scientific method as ways to better understand the world. Very frequently, we gather and assess evidence and determine that we simply don't know (the connection between electromagnetism and gravity for example). That's fine. Sometimes we posit tentative theories (multidimensions and string theory) that we recognize are not entirely proven. And sometimes we have an overwhelming body of evidence which allows us to make an informed conclusion about the world - gravity, nuclear fission, internal combustion engines, the Casimir effect, evolution, and god doesn't exist. We consider belief in things not seen or belief contrary to evidence to be a bad thing, not a good thing. We do not value faith. I think we have an opportunity to come together on points of ethics, politics, and actions in daily life. I think it will be much more difficult for us (theists and nontheists) to come together on the issue of the source of truth in the world. Jason

We consider belief in things not seen or belief contrary to evidence to be a bad thing, not a good thing. We do not value faith. I think we have an opportunity to come together on points of ethics, politics, and actions in daily life. I think it will be much more difficult for us (theists and nontheists) to come together on the issue of the source of truth in the world. Jason
